warningSignsHeading: Signs You May Need Storm Damage Electrical Repair
warningSignsSubheading: After a tropical storm or hurricane, property owners should be aware of potential failures in their electrical infrastructure. These conditions represent serious hazards that require isolation.

problems.title: Compromised Service Mast / Weather Head
problems.description: Damage to the structural pipe that attaches utility lines to the property prevents the safe restoration of power. Electrical certification is required for reconnection.

problems.title: Submerged Electrical Components
problems.description: Water intrusion into outlets, panels, or baseboard heaters leaves corrosive deposits that can lead to electrical failure or fire risk even after drying.

problems.title: Surge-Related Panel Failure
problems.description: High-voltage events during storms can cause mechanical failure in older electrical panels, evidenced by the smell of ozone or visible thermal damage.

problems.title: Partial Phase Failure (Lost Neutral)
problems.description: Symptoms such as flickering lights or only half of the property's circuits functioning indicate a serious failure in the main service lines.

problems.title: Improper Generator Integration
problems.description: Using portable generators without professional transfer switches can lead to dangerous backfeeding into the utility grid and property wiring.

problems.title: Structural Meter Enclosure Corrosion
problems.description: Storm-driven saline spray contributes to the rapid corrosion of the meter base, creating a potential fire hazard at the point of entry.

processHeading: How Our Storm Damage Electrical Repair Process Works

process.title: Hazard Assessment
process.description: The initial phase involves identifying and isolating immediate hazards such as downed lines or flooded circuits to stabilize the property.

process.title: Structural Reconstruction
process.description: Service masts and weather heads are rebuilt to meet current hurricane-rated electrical and building codes.

process.title: Regulatory Certification
process.description: A municipal inspection is performed to verify that the reconstructed service meets safety requirements for utility reconnection.

process.title: Utility Reconnection Signal
process.description: Following inspection approval, the required electrical certification is transmitted to the utility provider to authorize the reconnection of service.

process.title: Insurance Reporting
process.description: A technical report including photographic documentation of the damage and repairs is provided for property insurance documentation.

faqs.question: Is it safe to repair a damaged weather head manually?
faqs.answer: No. Working on a service entrance is hazardous due to the presence of high-voltage lines. Repairs must be performed by a licensed professional and inspected prior to use.

faqs.question: What parts of the service entrance are the homeowner's responsibility?
faqs.answer: While the utility provider manages the incoming wires, the mast, weather head, and meter base are part of the property's infrastructure and the owner's responsibility to maintain.

faqs.question: Can outlets that were affected by storm water be reused?
faqs.answer: Equipment that has been exposed to water typically requires replacement to prevent future thermal failure caused by internal corrosion and conductive mineral deposits.

faqs.question: How is power reconnection managed after a repair?
faqs.answer: Once repairs are completed and have passed a municipal safety inspection, the utility provider is notified that the system is safe to receive power.

faqs.question: Are emergency power solutions available during a restoration?
faqs.answer: Transfer switches and interlock kits can be integrated into the panel to allow for the safe use of portable power sources until utility service is restored.

faqs.question: Should I turn off my main breaker during a hurricane?
faqs.answer: If flooding is expected or you evacuate, yes—turn off the main breaker. This prevents damage to your electrical system from surges when power is restored. If you return to standing water near your panel, do not touch it—call a licensed electrician.

faqs.question: Does homeowner insurance cover storm electrical damage?
faqs.answer: Most Florida homeowner policies cover electrical damage from named storms, including panel replacement, rewiring, and service mast repair. We provide detailed damage documentation and repair estimates formatted for insurance claim submission.

faqs.question: How soon after a storm can electrical repairs begin?
faqs.answer: We begin assessments as soon as conditions are safe. Priority goes to homes with immediate safety hazards—downed service lines, water-damaged panels, and exposed wiring. Non-emergency repairs are typically scheduled within 24-48 hours of the storm passing.

seoContent.heading: Storm and Hurricane Electrical Repair in South Florida
seoContent.body: Professional electrical services are available for the repair of property infrastructure damaged by tropical storms and hurricanes. Technicians manage the requirements for service mast reconstruction and utility coordination throughout {county} and Broward. Every emergency call begins with a safety assessment. Our electricians use non-contact voltage testers, thermal imaging cameras, and circuit analyzers to identify the root cause—not just the symptom. We explain what we find in plain language before any work begins.

seoContent.heading: Service Entrance Reconstruction in Miami-Dade & Broward
seoContent.body: Rebuilding residential service masts to meet the latest NEC hurricane-zone requirements is a critical step in storm recovery. Licensed contractors handle the permitting and inspection processes necessary for the safe restoration of electrical power. South Florida's combination of aging infrastructure, lightning exposure, and high humidity creates unique emergency scenarios. Our electricians are trained to handle salt-air corrosion, water intrusion in panels, and surge damage from frequent thunderstorms.

seoContent.heading: Hurricane Season Electrical Preparedness in Miami
seoContent.body: South Florida's hurricane season runs June through November. Solomon Electric helps homeowners prepare with pre-storm electrical assessments, surge protection installation, generator hookups, and emergency service plans. Being prepared before the storm hits reduces damage and speeds recovery. We stock our service vehicles with the most commonly needed parts—breakers, GFCI outlets, wire nuts, connectors, and diagnostic equipment—so most emergency repairs are completed in a single visit without waiting for parts.

seoContent.heading: Post-Storm Electrical Safety Assessment in South Florida
seoContent.body: After a storm, never assume your electrical system is safe. Water infiltration, wind damage to service masts, and utility surges can create hidden hazards. Our licensed electricians perform thorough post-storm assessments, identify all damage, and coordinate with FPL and your insurance company for a complete restoration. After every emergency repair, we provide a written safety assessment and recommend any additional work needed to prevent recurrence. We never upsell unnecessary services, and our upfront pricing means no surprises on your bill.
